A translation moves a shape without changing its orientation.  Since the line segment is not rotated, it will not intersect with its original position during a translation.
A translation moves a shape without changing its orientation.  Since the line segment is only shifted, it will still intersect with its original position at a single point.
A horizontal line segment, when translated horizontally, will not intersect itself.
A vertical line segment will never intersect itself, regardless of the angle of translation.
A slanted line segment, when translated vertically, maintains its orientation. Since it's not changing direction, it won't intersect with its original position.
Translating a line segment horizontally doesn't change its orientation or intersections with itself.

A translation moves a shape without changing its orientation. Since the line segment is translated perpendicular to itself, it will slide along a path parallel to itself, never intersecting its original position.
Translating a horizontal line segment vertically upward creates a shape with parallel sides, making it a trapezoid.
Translating a line segment downward and connecting it to the original creates a shape with two parallel sides and two non-parallel sides, which is the definition of a trapezoid.
Shifting a horizontal line segment diagonally upward and connecting it to the original creates a trapezoid.
Translating a line segment doesn't change its shape. Connecting the translated segment to the original creates a trapezoid.
Translating an oblique line segment upward and connecting it to the original forms a trapezoid.
Translating a line segment doesn't change its shape.  Connecting the translated segment to the original will form a trapezoid.
Translating a vertical line segment horizontally creates a shape resembling a trapezoid.
Shifting a vertical line segment up and to the left by its own length will result in a trapezoid.
Translating a line segment doesn't change its shape.  Connecting the translated segment to the original will form a trapezoid.
Translating a line segment doesn't change its shape.  Connecting the translated segment to the original will form a trapezoid.
Rotating an object 180 degrees clockwise means flipping it upside down. Since the tail points north, the arrowhead will point south.
Rotating an object 180 degrees clockwise means turning it upside down. Since the arrow initially points east, rotating it 180 degrees clockwise will make it point west.
Rotating an object 90 degrees clockwise means turning it to the right. If the arrow starts pointing south, rotating it 90 degrees clockwise will make it point east.
A 270-degree counterclockwise rotation brings a horizontal ray pointing right, downwards.
Rotating a horizontal ray pointing left 90 degrees clockwise will cause it to point downwards.
Rotating a downward ray 90 degrees counterclockwise will cause it to point to the right.
Rotating 180 degrees clockwise is the same as rotating 180 degrees counterclockwise. This flips the direction of the ray.
Rotating a horizontal ray 90 degrees counterclockwise will cause it to point downwards.
Rotating a ray 270 clockwise brings it to the same position as the original ray, making them coincident.
Rotating a line by 45 degrees clockwise will result in a line that is parallel to the original line.
Rotating a line segment 180 clockwise around one of its endpoints will bring it to the exact same position, making it coincident with the original line segment.
Compressing one side of a line segment will shift the midpoint towards the compressed side.
Compressing the right half of the line segment will shorten it, pulling the midpoint towards the left.
The midpoint of a line segment is the average of its endpoints. If both ends are compressed towards the center by half, the average position will also remain the same.
Compressing a line segment vertically means shortening it while keeping its endpoints fixed.  This will move the midpoint of the new segment above the midpoint of the original segment.
Compressing a ray horizontally will make it appear more vertical. Imagine squeezing a long, thin rectangle; it will become shorter and wider.
Compressing a line segment from both ends while maintaining its midpoint will not change the position of the midpoint relative to itself.
Stretching one half of a line segment will shift the midpoint towards the direction of the stretch. Since the left half is stretched to the left, the midpoint will move left.
Stretching one half of a line segment will shift the midpoint towards the stretched side.
Stretching both sides of a line segment equally will not change the position of its midpoint.
